content: The 112th Congress used TPA authority to pass implementing bills for FTAs with Colombia, Panama, and South Korea in 2011. Other trade negotiations in progress that may require TPA include the Doha Development Round, TPP, TTIP, and TISA. Congress has granted the President TPA/fast track authority for over 40 years. The Trade Promotion Authority (TPA) allows Congress to vote on trade legislation without amendment if the President meets negotiating objectives and consultation requirements. TPA gives the President leverage in trade negotiations by assuring timely consideration by Congress. Renewal of TPA has become more controversial due to increased complexity in trade negotiations and partisan debates. The Trade Promotion Authority (TPA) has become more controversial as oversight and consultation requirements have increased, leading to a more partisan trade debate in Congress. The expiration of TPA raises questions about its renewal in terms of timing and form. TPA is the result of decades of cooperation and compromise between Congress and the executive branch, based on their constitutional powers and the need for flexibility in negotiating trade agreements. The partnership between Congress and the President on trade policymaking can be strengthened or strained depending on political and economic conditions. The U.S. Constitution assigns authority over foreign trade to Congress, giving them power to regulate commerce and collect taxes. The President has exclusive authority to negotiate treaties and agreements, with both branches involved in developing and executing trade agreements. Congress historically set tariff rates for imported products as the main trade policy instrument. In the first 150 years of the United States, Congress controlled foreign trade by setting tariff rates on imported products, which was the main trade policy and revenue source. Early trade debates divided Members from manufacturing and commodity exporting regions. The President's role was to negotiate treaties with MFN treatment. Two events in the 1930s transformed U.S. trade policy. In the 1930s, the Smoot-Hawley Tariff Act set high tariff rates, leading to retaliatory tariffs and worsening the Great Depression. In response, the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act of 1934 authorized the President to reduce tariffs through reciprocal trade agreements. The RTAA of 1934 authorized the President to enter reciprocal trade agreements reducing tariffs within pre-approved levels on an MFN basis. Congress delegated expanded trade authority to the President to lessen political pressure from special interests. The Smoot-Hawley Tariff Act was the last general tariff legislation, now only applied to imports from Cuba and North Korea without MFN status. Tariffs now only apply to imports from Cuba and North Korea without MFN status, referred to as normal trade relations status (NTR) in U.S. trade laws. Congress insured against executive branch overreach by subjecting trade agreements authority to periodic review and renewal. General tariff levels declined with the establishment of GATT in 1947, shifting trade negotiations from bilateral to multilateral forums. Trade negotiations expanded beyond tariffs. Under the Trade Expansion Act of 1962, Congress granted the President authority to negotiate tariff reductions and expanded its role in the process. The act allowed the President to conclude the GATT Kennedy Round, focusing on tariff reduction and nontariff barriers agreements. The GATT member countries reached agreements in the Kennedy Round related to nontariff barriers (NTBs), including customs valuation and antidumping practices. Congress believed the President exceeded his authority by negotiating these agreements, leading to a resolution in 1966 against "nontariff commitments." The Kennedy Round agreements on nontariff barriers led to a debate in Congress over presidential authority in trade negotiations. Congress sought a legislative remedy to address concerns of encroachment on its authority, leading to the creation of fast track authority for trade agreements. The Trade Expansion Act of 1962 expired in 1967, and it took seven years for Congress to renew the authority.
